title.value: Interacting Diffusion Processes for Event Sequence Forecasting
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper as mentioned at the top.
title.quote: Interacting Diffusion Processes for Event Sequence Forecasting

extractions.description: The paper presents a novel approach for forecasting event sequences using interacting diffusion processes. It aims to enhance long-horizon forecasting by modeling the sequences with coupled generative diffusion models that capture joint probability distributions of event types and inter-arrival times.

type.justification: The paper primarily focuses on demonstrating the empirical performance of the proposed model against state-of-the-art baselines through experimental evaluations.
type.quote: We demonstrate that our proposal outperforms state-of-the-art baselines for long-horizon forecasting of TPP.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is to predict sequences of events using a novel diffusion model.
name.quote: Our proposal is to tackle the multi-event forecasting problem by directly modelling a complete sequence of N events.

name.justification: The paper introduces a novel generative model for predicting event sequences.
name.quote: We build on recent advances in generative models, exploiting their impressive high-dimensionality modeling capabilities.

name.justification: The research leverages the framework of Temporal Point Processes for event sequence prediction.
name.quote: Neural Temporal Point Processes (TPPs) have emerged as the primary framework for predicting sequences of events that occur at irregular time intervals.

name.justification: CDiff is the proposed model in the paper which utilizes interacting diffusion processes for event sequence forecasting.
name.quote: We introduce our Cross-Diffusion (CDiff) model, which comprises two interacting diffusion processes.

is_contributed.justification: CDiff is introduced and thoroughly evaluated as the main contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce our Cross-Diffusion (CDiff) model, which comprises two interacting diffusion processes.

is_executed.justification: CDiff is evaluated using extensive experimental setups, which typically involve executing the model.
is_executed.quote: We train for a maximum of 500 epochs and report the best trained model based on the result of the validation set.

is_compared.justification: CDiff is compared with multiple state-of-the-art baselines in terms of forecasting accuracy and other metrics.
is_compared.quote: We compare our CDiff model with 4 state-of-the-art baselines for event sequence modeling.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The foundational concept of diffusion processes for generative modeling, which is extended in CDiff, is described in this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Following the conventional diffusion model setup (Ho et al., 2020), this marginalization can be approximated as: ...

name.justification: StackOverflow dataset is used in the paper for evaluations.
name.quote: Figure 1: Visualization of the cross-diffusion generating process for 15 examples sequences of the Stackoverflow dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: SNAP Datasets: Stanford large network dataset collection
referenced_paper_title.justification: It is a well-known dataset compilation referenced by the authors.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Leskovec, J. and Krevl, A. (2014). SNAP Datasets: Stanford large network dataset collection.

name.justification: Retweet dataset is used in the paper for evaluations.
name.quote: We use four real-world datasets: Taobao (Alibaba, 2018), which tracks user clicks made on a website; Taxi (Whong, 2014), which contains trips to neighborhood made by taxi drivers; StackOverflow (Leskovec and Krevl, 2014), which tracks the history of a post on stackoverflow; and Retweet (Zhou et al., 2013), which tracks the user interactions on social media posts.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning triggering kernels for multi-dimensional hawkes processes
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset citation is from the original paper referenced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Zhou, K., Zha, H., and Song, L. (2013). Learning triggering kernels for multi-dimensional hawkes processes.

name.justification: Taxi dataset is used in the paper for evaluations.
name.quote: We use four real-world datasets: Taobao (Alibaba, 2018), which tracks user clicks made on a website; Taxi (Whong, 2014), which contains trips to neighborhood made by taxi drivers; StackOverflow (Leskovec and Krevl, 2014), which tracks the history of a post on stackoverflow; and Retweet (Zhou et al., 2013), which tracks the user interactions on social media posts.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset citation is from the original paper referenced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Whong, C. (2014). Foiling nyc’s taxi trip data.

name.justification: Taobao dataset used in the paper for evaluations.
name.quote: We use four real-world datasets: Taobao (Alibaba, 2018), which tracks user clicks made on a website; Taxi (Whong, 2014), which contains trips to neighborhood made by taxi drivers; StackOverflow (Leskovec and Krevl, 2014), which tracks the history of a post on stackoverflow; and Retweet (Zhou et al., 2013), which tracks the user interactions on social media posts.

referenced_paper_title.value: User behavior data from taobao for recommendation
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset citation is from the original paper referenced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Alibaba (2018). User behavior data from taobao for recommendation.

name.justification: The paper uses a synthetic dataset generated from a multivariate Hawkes process for experimentation.
name.quote: Our synthetic dataset is generated from a Hawkes model.

referenced_paper_title.value: tick: a python library for statistical learning, with an emphasis on hawkes processes and time-dependent models
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is generated using the tick library as referenced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Bacry, E., Bompaire, M., Deegan, P., Gaı̈ffas, S., and Poulsen, S. V. (2018). tick: a python library for statistical learning, with an emphasis on hawkes processes and time-dependent models.

name.justification: The PyTorch library is used to implement the transformer-based components in their model.
name.quote: For the two diffusion denoising functions ϵθ (·), ϕθ (·), we adopt the PyTorch built-in transformer block (Paszke et al., 2019).

referenced_paper_title.value: Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library
